data.title: 7 Best Offbeat Places in Amritsar
data.meta_description: Let yourself dip into the offbeat Amritsar. Explore the offbeat places near Amritsar along with the unique attractions, and hidden gems that promise a sightseeing in Amritsar experience that is unforgettable.
data.text:
Amritsar, with itsGolden Temple and glorious history, often overshadows other less-known gems of the city. There is a lot more to this city for travelers looking at offbeat places in Amritsar or tours beyond the crowd. This is a guide through the travel itinerary and knowing some of the offbeat places in Amritsar and near Amritsar, guaranteeing you an awe moment.

1. Pul Kanjari

Pul Kanjari is really an offbeat destination that is approximately 35 km or so from Amritsar, taking its liking from many history lovers as well. It was previously known as Pul Moran and later formally known as Pul Kanjari. This is one of the offbeat places in Amritsar that one should and must visit.This ancient treasure is dedicated to the eternal love of Muslim dancer Moran and Maharaja Ranjit Singh Ji. It lies exactly at the Indo-Pak border. Maharaja Ranjit Singh also creates a village along the Pul Kanjari as a resting place to the army.

The period or the era of Maharaja Ranjit Singh is known as the golden era of Punjab, during this period Punjab saw great cultural and economic prosperity. Pul Kanjar is known as Punjab’s Taj Mahal.

The place hosts a historical baoli (stepwell), temple, mosque, and gurudwara epitomized respect by Maharaja for all religions. This is one of the finest offbeat places in Amritsar, with serene surroundings and rich history.

Location: 35 km away from Amritsar on Amritsar-Lahore Road

Visiting hours: 10 AM – 6 PM (All days accessible)

Suggested read: offbeat places in India

2. Sadda Pind

In this peculiar experience of sightseeing in Amritsar, one could never forget to visit Sadda Pind. This cultural village, at a distance of 8 km from the city, shall take you to the very roots of the tradition and simplicity of Punjabi life.

Right from its folk dances, music, and characteristic people to the authentic Punjabi cuisine, Sadda Pind is what it is, trying to display its lively celebration of the rich cultural heritage that showers Punjab. It happens to be one of the offbeat places in Amritsar and gives you an immersive cultural experience.

Location: Shagna Di Phulkari, behind Main Bypass Road, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, Punjab 143105

Visiting hours: 10.00 am to 10.30 pm

3. Ram Bagh Gate: A Forgotten Gem of Amritsar

Although not as famous as some other places in Amritsar, the story that the Ram Bagh Gate unravels about the city is just so absorbing that it deserves a visit. It is actually one of the better-preserved historical monuments of the city.

This gate historically led to the Summer Palace, or Ram Bagh Palace, from the Golden Temple and was one of 12 gates protecting the city from invaders. It speaks of the rich past and the lively present of Amritsar, with more enhancive renovations making it a sight of interest to tourists.

On entering the gate, you will be met with colored steel trunks narrating the story of the piteous ones who left these things behind during the partition of India in 1947. The bricks used herein are made in Nanakshahi style with lime instead of cement and give this gate a dignified look that seems ageless. Exploring Ram Bagh Gate is one of the offbeat places in Amritsar.

Location: Ram Bagh Chowk, Opposite Ram Bagh, Hall Bazar, Police Station, Amritsar.

Visiting Hours: Open to visitors all day.

Suggested read: Places to visit in Amritsar

4. Ram Tirath

Situated around 11 km from the heart of Amritsar, Ram Tirath may not be among the most often visited places in Amritsar, but it is very significant when it comes to mythology.

The town is believed to be the birthplace of Lav and Kush, sons of Lord Rama, and presently, it presides over an antique tank with many temples. An annual fair, which is organized here, draws scores of devotees and tourists alike to make this quirky place on the outskirts of Amritsar. It is one of the offbeat places near Amritsar.

Location: Ram Tirath temple, Amritsar, Kaler, Punjab 142043

Visiting Hours: 6.00 am to 8.00 pm, no entry fee

5. Harike Wetland and Bird Sanctuary

A true paradise for nature lovers, Harike Wetland is located at the confluence of the Beas and Sutlej rivers. The sanctuary abounds in various flora and fauna and is the habitat for a number of migratory birds that decide to set base here. The tranquil environs studded with rare birds make it one of the greatest offbeat places in Amritsar.

Location: 2 hr 10 min (89.8 km) via Shri Guru Nanak Dev Ji Marg/Tarn Taran – Kapurthala Rd

Visiting Hours: Open to visitors from 9 am to 4 pm ( closed on Saturdays)

6. Sarai Amanat Khan: A Glimpse into Mughal Heritage

Situated approximately 40 km from Amritsar, the Sarai Amanat Khan is an offbeat destination near Amritsar that dates back to as ancient times as that of the Mughal era. Constructed by the calligrapher of the Taj Mahal, Amanat Khan, this old caravanserai forms an outstanding example of beautiful intricate Mughal architecture and design, hence making this one of the foremost offbeat attractions in Amritsar.

It was one of the caravan stations along the Grand Trunk Road, of the type known as a central courtyard surrounded by rooms, despite being decked with exquisite calligraphy and patterns showing the artistic genius of that age. Its tranquil atmosphere and fine preservation have turned the building into a haven from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Sarai Amanat Khan is one of those rare experiences that brings together a bit of Mughal history and fine architectural style. It is an absolute must-visit place for those who wish to go back in time and explore some of the lesser-known but equally magnificent places and offbeat places in Amritsar.

Location: This hidden gem can be visited on the outskirts of Amritsar city, which is about 40 km away.

Visiting Hours: Visitors are allowed at all times

Suggested read: Adventure activities in Amritsar

7. Quila Ahluwalia

One of the prime examples of the historic heritage and exquisite architecture of Punjab is Quila Ahluwalia, a fort located in the middle of the old city. The fort was originally constructed by Jassa Singh Ahluwalia, the leader of the Ahluwalia Misl, as a comforting base during his visits to Harimandir Sahib. After Jassa Singh’s death, the fort was managed by his successors, who enhanced its defensive features. In 1802, Maharaja Ranjit Singh Ji, who headed the Shukarchakiya Misl, took possession of the fort and formed a friendly alliance with Fateh Singh, the Chief of the Ahluwalia Misl.

He further invited many cloth traders and business people of the Marwari clan to settle more in the markets around the fort, so as to enhance the economy of Amritsar. This build-up of the textile market became very famous all over India in no time. Quila Ahluwalia is, without a doubt, a place that you should visit when you come to Amritsar as it is one of the offbeat places in Amritsar.

Location: This marvelous architecture is placed in the narrow lanes near Dharam Singh Market.

Visiting Hours: Open to visitors at all times.

Conclusion
